Short answer: if you compress air extremely (which makes it really hot, Boyle's law), and use something like water to cool the compressed air  back to room temperature, and then allow it to expand back to 1 bar pressure, you should up with liquid air 😉   Air Liquide and other industrial suppliers does this on an industrial scale every day, and purifies the various gasses (nitrogen, oxygen, and argon) by allowing them to gas off at their respective boiling  points.  You reliquify the pure gas that evaporates, and you end up with pure liquid nitrogen, oxygen, and argon!

When I worked at Micron semiconductors in Boise Idaho I noticed in the first few months of working there that there were people that appeared to have big purple birthmarks on their faces and arms. So, when liquifying a gas, it is handy to place the container on a scale during the process. As the gas liquifies, it becomes more dense. More dense, but same volume = more mass. More mass in a non-inertial frame of reference (ie, a "gravity field") has more "weight". You can then check the scale during the process without disturbing the process, to see if, and how much, liquified gas you have created.

Second, it comes off as pretty arrogant, given that , by the time I stopped watching, you had "professionally" dumped a bunch of liquid air into a glass beaker way too fast and without eye protection... which would or should get you a stern talking to in any undergrad lab or any modern trade apprenticeship. Pyrex is not magic. Third, the whole point of this kind of education is to teach people to do things and verify things for themselves. "Don't try this at home" is a demoralizing and destructive attitude. Fourth, if you actually care about riski, then it's far more effective to teach the precautions ... taking care to learn them yourself first, of course. Fifth, replicating the video would require thousands of dollars worth of equipment, and most people who would even know where to source that equipment probably know more about safety (and about how to do the task) than you do.

How about the Haber-Bosch Process, which is a complex chemical procedure that takes nitrogen from the air and under high pressures and temperatures combines it with hydrogen to produce ammonia. This ammonia is the base of the synthetic nitrogen fertilizers increasingly used around the world today. Without this fertilizer, farmers couldn't produce enough food for the world population, but this process consumes a huge amount of energy which injects tons of carbon into the atmosphere, helping the global warming crises....isn't science wonderful.....

Using a helium/Stirling cryocooler is cheating.  Let's see you do this using only compression and expansion, as liquid air was originally made (in the 19th century, before helium was even known).  Hint: the first refrigeration used air as the working fluid.  Compress, dump the heat of compression into water, expand, and suck heat out of a reservoir (they used brine).  That gets you cold brine, cold enough to make ice.  Now use the cold brine as the heat sink for another stage, and cool something with a much lower freezing point -- like ethanol, methanol, or acetone.  One or two more stages and you'll be able to use the air in the system with a phase change, like the refrigerant in modern heat pumps, freezers, and air conditioners -- and the cold side will be filled with liquid air.  Distill to obtain pure nitrogen and liquefy that again, and done.  BTW, a minor variation of this (using modern refrigeration to cut the number of stages needed) is used for commercial production of both liquid nitrogen and liquid oxygen, and pure compressed gases like nitrogen, oxygen, argon, and carbon dioxide (all obtained by distilling liquefied air).

There are obvious dangers when fooling with liquid nitrogen, burns and tissue death, etc.  There are subtle dangers as well:  Working in a fume hood or area of small volume...as it vaporizes, it displaces surrounding air.  The signal to breathe comes from carbon dioxide buildup on lung tissue, not the lack of oxygen.  So you pass out without warning, fall back and fracture your head on the Instron.  Oh yeah!  Don't spill liquid nitrogen on old lab reports; it cools the paper below the condensation point of oxygen, which condenses out on the papers, which burst into flame, igniting the  ether/acetone mixture behind you. I used to test superconducting magnets at Fermilab in Batavia, IL. The cryocooler needed backpressure to operate efficiently, so a bare copper tube carried the liquified gas, and air would condense on it and drip off. Catch that liquid in a styrofoam cup, and the nitrogen boils off, leaving pale blue liquid O2. Pour a quarter cup of that into an empty one litre pop bottle, cap it, and you have a powerful explosive when pressure builds up. Toss it about 50 feet and when it hits the ground you have a really satisfying explosion. Or, just let it sit and STEP BACK. Fun times.

But why were the nitrogen bubbles going up in the middle of the glass and not just going up everywhere?  I think I know the real answer to why the bubbles were descending on the outside.  It's probably because they store the empty glasses in the freezer.  When they're filled with coffee, the freezing cold glass cools the coffee next to it so the coffee gets colder and therefore denser all around the perimeter than in the middle so it creates a current that's descending all around the outside and flowing to the middle and back up to the top then flowing back out to the sides again.  Once the temperature of the glass and the coffee reach equilibrium, the current would stop.

I think the large dewar being empty of liquid comes down to thermal mass and the rate of generation of the liquid nitrogen. In short the massive metalic suface area  and thermal capacity of the dewar conducted heat at a rate faster than than the LN could cool it despite the insulation. Now try doing it really from scratch, which is length of copper tube with a coil in it that is air cooled followed by a coil of copper in a Dewar with a restricting nozzle exiting into the Dewar. And a compressor blowing into it.

Somewhere I have an old chemistry textbook [edited by Linus Pauling, iirc?] that has among other illustrations, the setup you need to liquefy air. It's basically a pinhole orifice, an inexhaustible supply of compressed air and an icewater bath [to pre-cool the air line leading to the orifice.] The line leading to the orifice runs in front of the jet, so the expanding gas cools the line further, leading to even cooler gas leaving the orifice, cooling the line even more, rinse lather repeat. Keep the pressure high enough long enough iced enough, and eventually liquid air starts dripping off the orifice... Liquid nitrogen is just a fractional distillation away at that point [let all the liquid oxygen evaporate, then what you have left is mostly LN3...]

Why are you not wearing chemical gloves when handling liquid nitrogen? Don't care about getting burned? Also, your info about nitrogen infused coffee isn't really correct. Nitrogen cannot dissolve into a beverage like CO2 can, and "nitro" beverages are all (beer included) still carbonated, just at a smaller volume than other drinks. Nitrogen (or any inert gas...argon for example) is often used to drive a draft system, because a low co2 amount wouldn't give enough pressure for most systems, especially the stout tap that is used to knock some CO2 out of suspension.

Guys, rule #1 working with compressed nitrogen, avoid working in a closed room. Remember that unconsciousness and death from oxygen deprivation comes before you even recognize the problem. This is different from holding your breath or rebreathing same air as there is no accumulation of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. People go through special training just to be able to recognize oxygen deprivation early enough that they have couple of seconds to react. Read this: https://www.quora.com/What-will-happen-if-Im-in-a-room-full-of-nitrogen-gases . It is not uncommon for multiple people to just die completely unaware there is any problem: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f2ItJe2Incs

At 9:30 the reason the big dewar was not filling is because it has a huge thermal mass. These dewars need a few(2-3) litres of liquid nitrogen just to get the inside to -196degC. The crycooler with around 5w of cooling power at -196degC would need 1 or 2 days just to get the insides of the dewar cold enough so LN2 will be able to stay there. After cooldown the dewar is by far the best to get the cryocooler liquify gas inside. Especially this model (YDS-10) if not mistaken which has an evaporation rate of 0,1litres per day

I used to make 99.9 oxygen liquid and nitrogen liquid. We used a 1 ton oxygen/nitrogen plant. For the Goverment. Compressed air into a distillation column using crude oxygen to maintain the balance and scrubbed the liquid until all other gases boil off leaving the nitrogen liquid. It was fun and took about 8 hours to maintain the purity.

Derek, I love your channel, but don't you think it's a bit dishonest to say you are making liquid nitrogen from scratch? You bought a cryocooler and turned it on. Also, you really need to mention safety. "Don't try this at home" isn't sufficient anymore: we've heard it so many times that nobody cares. People need to know how it is dangerous. Eating liquid nitrogen prepared desserts can be dangerous if not prepared properly, a boy in Korea got a hole cold-burned in his stomach from this and the FDA has sent out a warning about it. I'm not saying don't do it, it's a lot of fun, but you need to be clear about safety. Vendors at fairs like to serve these sorts of things to wow guests, but they usually have no training or safety precautions. You probably have some safety precautions doing this in your house, but we don't see that. You are a popular and respected source of information in this world, and I hope that you can use a little bit to spread safety as well.

Carbonic acid is what makes carbonated beverages feel carbonated, it isn't the CO2 bubbles at all. This has been tested in hyperbaric chambers. And this is also why other gasses[ N2, O2, Ar...] don't work for that fizzy mouthfeel.
Guinness and related "cream ales" use a 25%CO2 75% N2 blend so they have the fine foam without tasting completely flat.

When you are pouring Guinness from a tap, the same bubble effect will happen. They use nitrogenisization to create the unique smooth texture in their stout.

The nitrogen in Guinness creates the same downward cloud (micro bubble) effect which they call the “surge”. It is also why draught Guinness has a creamy white head despite being ruby red (much like the coffee here). In cans of draught Guinness there is a widget inside the can which releases nitrogen into the beer when the can is opened to give the beer the same creaminess and to create the surge as Guinness served on draught. That is why cans of Guinness draught should be poured and not consumed from the can. Sixty Symbols with Brady Harlan and Phil Moriarty did a video on it here. https://youtu.be/qNBTygWcy0s

Liquid air is about 70% oxygen (boiling point of oxygen is roughly 20K higher than that of nitrogen - it is easier to liquify and the oxygen/nitrogen ratio in the liquid air reflects that. That's essentially how we put nitrogen in tires when I was working as a mechanic. It used shop air, a similar filter shown here, and we could pump straight out of a second air connection to fill tires. Well, until it was decided to just use nitrogen for our air tools, too. To make the fill "pure," we used a machine that pulled a vacuum in the tire to remove as much air as possible - twice - then filled back with nearly pure nitrogen. What makes nitrogen good for tire fills is that it will expand and contract less than ambient air does and (supposedly) the nitrogen molecule didn't find a way past the synthetic rubber and steel belts of the tires at the atomic level. We certainly noticed the difference because every late fall, when air temperatures got colder, we had a run of customers that used regular air with check tire pressure lights on.

Also, as a note, if you do get a nitrogen fill but need to keep your tire pressures correct, it is ok to fill with regular air. You're just reducing the purity of the nitrogen content in your tire and nothing more. The more important part is to make sure your tire is filled to the correct pressures. Your sidewalls flex way more than you realize and that flexing gets worse with low tire pressure. If you've ever noticed a perfect ring of a tire carcass where it's just the tread and no sidewall, it's because the sidewall failed from overstress and overheating. If you notice a brown colored ring around the sidewall, that is your last chance indicator that you're about to lose it and need to buy a new tire. If you do get the chance to replace it (because if you see that, it's done regardless), your technician or tire changer will probably have a hand full of rubber balls from inside the tire. That's the sidewall debris from wearing on the inside.

Cool video, but lets not forget how dangerous nitrogen can potentially be, especially in an enclosed area.  It only takes a few breaths of pure nitrogen to kill you.  It is one of the fastest acting asphyxiates because we can't smell it, taste it, and it won't trigger a panic reflex like other gases will.  You just simply pass out.  It's crazy to think that it makes up 78 percent of the air we breath.   But when nitrogen displaces the oxygen we breath from 20.9 percent to 6 percent or you will go into a comma in 40 seconds or less.  Passing out in that kind of environment will with out a doubt kill you.  I work in the petrochemical industry and nitrogen is use everywhere for fire and explosion prevention purposes.  For me, it is the most feared gases to be around.  It's the silent killer, one second your here, the next your not.
You dont make it you produce it.

One way to bring in just the right amount of nitrogen is to seal the cryogenic cooler end, and your intake air, just put a T there. Any excess pressure exit via the T instead of via the flask. Put a piece of cloth over the open end of the T as to avoid normal air from contaminating the nitrogen. Now, all you need to do is make sure that the flow is barelly higher than the cooler want.


A better setup would be to use some sort of valve like scuba drivers use for their breathing apparatus, that only bring air if there is a demand... But that get more complicated for such a setup.

Ambient (dry) air = 78% N₂ + 21% O₂ + 1% Ar + small fractional %ages of other gases.
So when you were reading the O₂ level with that meter, and calling out 99.8% N₂ based on the O₂ reading of 0.2%, were you sure that the microfiber filtration mechanism was removing Ar as well as all the other gases?

And when you were liquefying air, I thought you might remove the O₂ by fractional distillation, because (at 1 atm), O₂ boils at 90K, while N₂ boils at 77K.
But then I was wondering how you'd collect just the N₂ in order to reliquefy it. (BTW, Ar boils at 87K.)
The way you did it was much smarter – remove the O₂ before liquefaction.

In any case, thanks for a fantastic excursion through some really neat equipment!

Thoughts for slowly introducing the room temperature N2 into the cooler area. You need some check valves. First make sure you can seal the cooler onto your vacuum flask. Have a vent check-valve or pressure relief valve to keep the cryo area safe from inadvertent over pressurization. A flapper valve that you can blow open would be enough. Put a regulator on the output of your N2 tank, set to about 1 PSIg. Connect the regulator to your cooler assembly through a 1 PSI check valve. That way as the N2 condenses and lowers the pressure in the cooler assembly below ambient, the check valve is allowed to open, replacing the volume of condensed N2 with fresh gaseous N2, but the flow rate should be slow enough to keep from pulling too much heat into the cooler.
It may be difficult to find a regulator that can output as low as 1PSIg, so in that case, use a higher pressure check valve, and set the regulator's output to the same pressure as the check valve. That way a slight vacuum on the check valve is what is required to slightly open it. (And maybe the pressure drop across the check valve can be utilized as pre-chilling your N2?)

Two Easiest Ways To Win the Nobel Prize


1. Prove light must coexist with matter, and there is no light wave in the vacuum of space.

The most famous double slit experiment is a misinterpretation. Do a new double slit experiment in a vacuum, and the light will not show wave property.

The first person to do a double slit experiment in a vacuum, to prove there is no light wave in the vacuum of space, can win a Nobel and change history.

If you have the tools, you should take this unique opportunity.

Put the slits and screen on the inside walls of a square glass container. Point a laser beam on the slits, video the light wave interference on the screen. Then vacuum seal the container, video the interference disappear and leave two bright lines on the screen as if light acts as a particle.

In fact, light is not a wave, not a particle in the vacuum of space. A light wave is a vibrating electrostatic force carried by vibrating electrons/atoms propagating in a matter/medium.

Crookes radiometer spins in a low vacuum, but it does not spin in a hard/high vacuum. This proves light is not photon particles that have momentum. Scientists denied to see the fact.

2. Measure light speed in a vacuum glass bottle to prove it is infinite.

Use MIT 10 trillion frames per second camera to measure light speed in a vacuum glass bottle, we can prove light speed in vacuum is infinite, and there is no light propagating in the vacuum of space at light speed

12:39 Derek, this explanation makes no sense! If there really was such a convection effect, the bubbles would be rising on the warmer outside of the glass, rather than the cooler center. Moreover, the residual current from pouring with the tap would also motivate an inside-down direction. I do not think there is any convection going on here at all.

What you're seeing coming down on the sides of the glass are not bubbles, rather you're seeing sheets of coffee forming and sinking. If the bubbles were big enough to track individually, any one of them would still rise; it's just that since they're too small to see, you aren't seeing them. You just see the coffee gathering together due to liquid cohesion and sinking. It's sort of counterintuitive, in the same way that a helium balloon inside a car will "lean into" a turn.

@Veritasium I have to disagree with you at 4:00
If you use a magnet to attract the liquid oxygen in liquid air, the oxygen and the nitrogen should stick to the magnet. The nitrogen shouldn't be left alone unless it's being strongly repelled.

What's actually going on is likely fractional distillation. Liquid nitrogen has a boiling point of 77 K, and liquid oxygen has a boiling point of 90 K. This means the nitrogen has a much higher vapor pressure and boils away first, leaving the oxygen concentrated. So when you pulled up the droplet of liquid air, it probably evaporated the nitrogen and left oxygen concentrated.

In fact, I've liquified air with liquid nitrogen. Liquid air boils at 83 K and probably gives off well over 95% nitrogen gas, despite the liquid being 20% oxygen. Because of this, you can actually put out a flame with liquid air, and then do the opposite when the oxygen concentrates. The boiling point will slowly rise from 83 K towards 90 K

So you're asking, "Why do we need an alarm for low oxygen? Wouldn't we notice if there was nothing to breath?" Surprisingly, no you would not realize you're not breathing any oxygen. When you hold your breath, the burning sensation and discomfort you feel is not lack of oxygen, it's build up of carbon dioxide, which is kind of poison. If you were to walk into something, like a massive rocket fuel tank in order to inspect it, and it was filled with something like argon, to prevent fires, you would happily breath it in, none the wiser, and then pass out in seconds with no warning. So for people who do things like welding, and aerospace, anywhere you may have air displaced with an inert gas, you have these meters to tell you if the air where you're working is oxygenated air, or if it will kill you.

the cascading effect (which we've known for years due to nitro served beers) is also a bit of an optical illusion. The BUBBLES are rising, but they are very dense and very small, so the waves that are descending are mostly the liquid, sort of washing downward around the essentially clumps of bubbles. Look closely - the lighter colored bubbles are not descending, it is the darker colored liquid which is descending in waves. Really neat! BTW - the typical gas that beer is served on (as well as coffee) is NOT pure Nitrogen, it is called "Beer Gas" or "Beer Mix" and is 75% N2 and 25% CO2. With beer (like Guinness) - it is carbonated as normal, on CO2 (since N2 is VERY not soluble) and then SERVED on Beer Gas using what's called a sparkler plate (small plate with tiny holes) which mixes the liquid up with all of the nitrogen and CO2 in solution and stirs it. That agitation releases most of what's in solution and gives even more of that cascading effect. It also is a bit of a flow control since you have to serve Beer Gas at 30psi instead of around 12psi for normal CO2. Do that on a regular tap and you have a JET. . . from experience. . . LOL. Mixed up the hoses. Much laughter. Anyway - good vid. Fun stuff! :)

Cool, thanks for that. Back in the late 70s I used to work with cryogenically cooled parametric amplifiers for receiving weak signals. The system ran at 17 to 19 K nominally. The cooling element we used was not that much different than what you showed in the video.


The amplifier assembly was placed inside a dewar assembly sucked down to nearly a perfect vacuum and it was neat to watch the vacuum and temperature drop together as the system was reaching its nominal operating temperature.


The system ran on helium of course, but one day one of the techs mistakenly topped off the compressor with nitrogen instead of helium. It was like throwing sand down the carburetor of a car engine. The nitrogen froze and damaged the cooling piston and took us off the air till I rebuilt the unit.

I think the explanation of why the bubbles move down is pretty weak.  You can see that the drink actually accumulates at the bottom as more and more bubbles fall, so I'd say that the bubbles are being pulled down by the liquid coming out of being "held" by the foam, and as the liquid accumulates, it can now drag bubbles down with it.  The column of nitrogen bubbles going up is the consequence of this interaction, not the cause.

You can make your own homemade liquid nitrogen using readily available materials. It's not really liquid nitrogen, however, but cryogenic-temperature alcohol. Chilled alcohol can be used for many liquid nitrogen projects, such as freezing flowers or other materials. It is not suitable for ice cream or anything edible.
